ğ„ğˆğ‘ğ„ğ’ ğğğ¨ğ©ğ¥ğ | We're happy to welcome Assistant Professor Lenneke Kuijer to the EIRES management team as of May 2024. Alongside Lisanne Havinga, MSc. PhD, she will lead the Energy Transition in the Built Environment focus area.ğŸ‘ Lenneke's innovative approach integrates social science methods into energy research, aiming to better define problems and improve solution efficacy. Her journey, from her early fascination with technology to her work on sustainability, showcases her commitment to challenging conventional thinking. A highlight is her Veni-project on summer comfort, where she used speculative design to expand the design space. This led to BRYS, an interface design for thermostats that encourages natural temperature regulation. At EIRES, Lenneke aims to create a collaborative platform, bridging social sciences and engineering to address built environment challenges. Read the full interview hereğŸ‘‰ https://lnkd.in/e8GnFR_T #EnergyTransition #Sustainability #SocialScience #Engineering #Innovation

Last month, the researchers and principal investigators involved in the first nine projects of the BEHeaT program gathered for a pitch event to strengthen the interaction between and integration of the different projects. ğŸŒ The event promoted unique collaboration through an innovative approach - presenting each other's work. This method significantly enhanced mutual understanding and opened new avenues for interdisciplinary integration. Erik Matien, EIRES Senior Program Manager, emphasized the importance of collaboration from the research phase to achieve the energy transition in the built environment. The BEHeaT program, initiated in January 2023, aims to grow into a national initiative, with a focus on Technology Readiness Levels 5 to 7. ğŸš€ Read more here: https://lnkd.in/eJ-AjwEY #EnergyTransition #ResearchCollaboration #Sustainability

Which incentives are most effective in keeping our energy grid accessible? TU/e researchers have analyzed the most popular measures and come to a conclusion: a balanced set of different incentives works best! In their research, which they performed together with TNO, PhD students Bart van der Holst and Gijs Verhoeven analyzed financial measures for grid operators to better use the existing grid capacity. Their conclusion: a smart set of balanced measures is the best solution to keep the energy grid accessible in the short and the long term! Therefore, their supervisor, EIRES Professor Koen Kok, advises: "The time to design solutions is now because we need to be better equipped to deal with the current and future net congestion." Read moreğŸ‘‰https://lnkd.in/eN-mzZXH #netcongestion #energyresearch #energytransition

With the onset of summer, the temperature's rising, and the sun is out again in the Netherlands. It's time to think about keeping our living and working spaces cool. â„ï¸ EIRES principal scientist Lenneke Kuijer concluded her research to summer comfort this year by presenting a concept thermostat BRYS. BRYS will help you keep your home up to nine degrees Celsius cooler than the outside, and it will help you train your body's comfort range. This will help you to stay cool during the summer without using energy-intensive appliances and air conditioners. She did her research and design work with partners in the cooling and ventilation branche and housing associations, among others. Read more about her thought provoking work ğŸ‘‰https://lnkd.in/eWPZuG-h

Great news: CyanO2 wins the tenth edition of the TU/e Contest with a bioreactor to capture COâ‚‚! ğŸ‰ The team from the TU/e Honors Academy track Energy, guided by Mark Cox and Han van Kasteren, is working on a new technology to capture COâ‚‚ and convert it into raw materials for the chemical industry. "About 25% of global COâ‚‚ emissions come from industry," states Gabrielle Mathieu, business developer at CyanO2, while pitching her company to the audience. In various chemical processes, such as cement production, COâ‚‚ is released. Therefore, several companies focus on capturing COâ‚‚ from the air. They then store this in the ground, she outlines. But COâ‚‚ can also be cleverly reused. That's why the students devised a bioreactor in which the captured COâ‚‚ is converted into raw materials by cyanobacteria. Those materials can then be used again in various industries, such as the cement industry, thus establishing a circular model. "This way, we have gains on two fronts," she said. Congratulations Cristina Jimenez Pelarda, Gabrielle Mathieu, Matylda Guz, and Raya Dimitrova! ğŸ‘ Read more about the TU/e contest: https://lnkd.in/ekZrtms5 ğŸ“· Bart van Overbeeke

Lunch is included ğŸ¥ª Joining online is also possible This lunch lecture is scheduled as follows: ğŸ“† Friday 28 June 2024 âŒšï¸ 12h00-13h00 ğŸ“ Disruptor building, Horsten 1 Eindhoven or online ğ—Ÿğ—¶ğ˜ğ—µğ—¶ğ˜‚ğ—º ğ—§ğ—¿ğ—®ğ—»ğ˜€ğ—½ğ—¼ğ—¿ğ˜ ğ—¶ğ—» ğ—˜ğ—½ğ—¶ğ˜ğ—®ğ˜…ğ—¶ğ—®ğ—¹ ğŸ®ğ—— ğ—®ğ—»ğ—± ğŸ¯ğ—— ğ—§ğ—µğ—¶ğ—» ğ—™ğ—¶ğ—¹ğ—ºğ˜€ ğ—³ğ—¼ğ—¿ ğ—¦ğ—¼ğ—¹ğ—¶ğ—±-ğ—¦ğ˜ğ—®ğ˜ğ—² ğ— ğ—¶ğ—°ğ—¿ğ—¼ğ—¯ğ—®ğ˜ğ˜ğ—²ğ—¿ğ—¶ğ—²ğ˜€ Miniaturizing energy storage devices to the microscale is crucial for advanced applications like communication and health monitoring. Current microbatteries suffer from limited performance and degradation, requiring major improvements. Key challenges include enhancing energy capacity, charging rate, safety, cycle life, and material availability. The main issue is poor reversibility at the electrode-electrolyte interfaces, leading to short battery life due to parasitic reactions and structural changes. Thin film epitaxial microbattery architectures enable precise control over materials and interfaces, offering insights into electrochemistry and structural ordering. Using pulsed laser deposition, researchers have created controlled 2D and 3D interfaces, advancing our understanding of battery performance. The latest research involves various thin film battery architectures with different cathodes, anodes, and solid electrolytes. This lunch lecture is organized by Mariadriana Creatore. Sign up here: â¬‡ï¸ https://lnkd.in/e3THEEpK Don't miss this opportunity to learn about cutting-edge developments in microbattery technology! Battery Competence Cluster - NL #energy #energytransition #renewableenergy
